mdRecord.dcterms:title: Monroe Hill, interior|general view
Monroe Hill House
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Sitting room (106) facing southwest, showing filled-in doorway to parlor (105), before renovation

Property purchased 1790 by James Monroe, who built a brick dwelling, brick law office, and frame kitchen on the site. Property purchased 1814 by John Perry, one of Jefferson’s builders, who enlarged the house. Perry sold the property 1817 to be held in trust for the future University of Virginia. House used as a residence for the University Proctor until it was appropriated for student housing; in 1848 two arcaded ranges, Dawson’s Row and Brown Range, were constructed as additional student housing. House remodeled late 19th century. Complex became the University’s first residential college, now called Brown College, 1986 and the house became the principal’s residence. — National Register of Historic Places nomination form, September 2003 [work]
mdRecord.dcterms:isPartOf: James Murray Howard University of Virginia Historic Buildings and Grounds Collection
